newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian BBL sees FY96 pft growing 18 pct.
newsitem.headline: Belgian BBL sees FY96 pft growing 18 pct.

text.p: Bank Bruxelles Lambert SA confirmed analysts expectations on Wednesday about the health of Belgian bank profits in 1996, reporting earnings jumped 18 percent in the six-months to June 30 and predicting similar growth for the whole year.
"These results tell us a lot about what will happen this year," chief executive officer Daniel Cardon de Lichtbuer told journalists.
BBL, the first of Belgium's big banks to release interim 1996 earnings, said half-year net profit rose to 5.07 billion Belgian francs ($165.9 million) from 4.30 billion in the year-earlier period.
Analysts polled by Reuters earlier this week predicted a profit in the range of 4.9 to 5.1 billion francs.
BBL said it was helped by a favourable interest rate environment and sharp rise in trading and other income.
Net interest income -- the difference paid on deposits and income received on longer-term loans -- rose 12 percent to 26.40 billion from 23.58 billion Belgian francs.
Trading and commission income rose 32 percent to 17.83 billion francs, with the biggest rise being recorded in forex and securities trading, up 56 percent to 4.93 billion francs.
Cardon said that without increased provisions, in part to prepare for the arrival of Europe's single currency, and higher taxes the rise in earnings would have been stronger.

Pre-tax profit was up 25 percent at 9.31 billion francs, he noted. Depreciation, write-downs and provisions -- which included a first 500 million franc charge for the introduction of the euro -- rose 42 percent to 8.63 billion francs.

Cardon predicted BBL would have to spend about 1.4 billion Belgian francs, plus an additional two percent-a-year in operating costs over four years to update accounting and computer systems and train staff to handle the euro.

Cardon -- who retires at the end of this year -- said BBL had now fulfilled the financial targets he set when he took over as chief executive four years ago at the end of a battle for control over the bank between shareholders Groupe ING and Groupe Bruxelles Lambert.
The bank, as expected, named director Michel Tilmant, a former JP Morgan executive, as his successor.
Cardon admitted, however, he would probably leave the bank before steering it to an alliance with a domestic or foreign partner -- a goal he made public in a newspaper interview in August 1995.
It emerged earlier this year that ING had blocked a possible link between BBL and Generale Bank, Belgium's biggest bank.
"Everything for the moment is at a standstill, certainly for the coming months and perhaps years. Everybody is looking at the future...(but) there's no obvious solution," Cardon said.
He repeated however his belief that Belgium was overbanked and that some form of shakeup would come, either before or after the introduction of the euro in 1999.
Belgium's other main banks - Generale Bank, Credit Communal de Belgique/Gemeentekrediet (CCB) and Kredietbank - publish their results on September 10, 11 and 12.
The head of French Credit Local de France - with whom CCB plans to link later this autumn - said on Wednesday CCB would report "very favourable, I could even say excellent profits."
